columns.text: In this problem, we will analyze whether replacing an asset would beneficial for the firm and what cashflows the replacement will bring.

**a.** For this section, we must first solve for the depreciation of the asset. We will use the straight-line method which means that we will simply take the initial investment then divide it by the number of years. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$1,872,000}{5}\\[15 pt]
&=\$374,400
\end{aligned}$$

Throughout its lifespan, the machine will lose $\$374,400$ per year in terms of its value.

Next, we will solve for the operating cash flow of the new machine. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\text{Savings} \times(1-\text{Tax rate})\\
&+(\text{Depreciation} \times \text{Tax rate})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$348,000 \times(1-0.22)+(\$374,400\times 0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$353,808
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow that the new machine brings is $\$353,808$

We will now solve for the after-tax salvage value which will be added into the cash flow for the fifth year. To do this, simply multiply the salvage value by 1 minus the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$360,000 \times(1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$280,800
\end{aligned}$$

The after-tax salvage value is $\$280,800$

Using the formula for the net present value, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\$353,808}{(1+0.12)^1}+\dfrac{\$353,808}{(1+0.12)^2}+\dfrac{\$353,808}{(1+0.12)^3}\\
&+\dfrac{\$353,808}{(1+0.12)^4}+\dfrac{\$353,808+\$280,800}{(1+0.12)^5}-\$1,872,000\\[15 pt]
&=-\$437,721.82
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the firm when using the new equipment is $-\$437,721.82$

Now we will use an annuity table to check for the corresponding factor. In the case of 5-years with an expected return of $12\%$, the annuity factor is $3.6047762$.

Substitute the values to the formula for the Equivalent Annual Cost:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equivalent Annual Cost}&=\dfrac{-\$437,721.82}{3.6047762}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$121,428.29
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost of the new equipment is $-\$121,428.29$

To solve for the cash flow, we can simply multiply the depreciation by the tax rate:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\$312,000 \times 0.22\\[15 pt]
&=\$68,640
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for the old equipment is $\$68,640$

The opportunity cost refers to the loss of value that will be obtained if this option gets chosen. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Opportunity cost}&=\text{Market price}+((\text{Depreciation}\times\text{remaining years})-\text{Market price})\times \text{Tax rate})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Opportunity cost}&=\$504,000+((\$312,000 \times 3)-\$504,000)\times0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$599,040
\end{aligned}$$

If we continue investing in this old machine, then the opportunity cost is $\$599,040$

We will now solve for the after-tax salvage value of this old machine. To do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\text{Salvage value}+((\text{Depreciation}-\text{Salvage value})\times \text{tax rate})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$144,000+((\$312,000-\$144,000)\times0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$180,960
\end{aligned}$$

After-tax salvage value is $\$180,960$

Now to solve for the net present value, we will substitute the known values to the formula in Step 10:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=-\$599,040+\dfrac{\$68,640}{1+0.12}\\
&+\dfrac{\$68,040+\$180,960}{(1+0.12)^2}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$339,253.01
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value for the old equipment is $-\$339,253.01$

Now to solve for the Equivalent Annual Cost, we will use the same formula as was used in the new equipment but this time, the annuity factor is $1.690051$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equivalent Annual Cost}&=\dfrac{-\$339,253.01}{1.690051}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$200,735.37
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost for this is $-\$200,735.37$
Since the estimated annual cost of the new machine is lower than that of the old machine, then we should replace the old machine.

**b.** In this part of the problem, we will solve for the difference in the net present value by subtracting the NPV of the new machine by the NPV of the old machine per year then taking the total.

Difference in Year 0 or the initial investment:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference in NPV}&=-\$1,872,000-(-\$599,040)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$1,272,960
\end{aligned}$$

Difference in Year 1:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference in NPV}&=\$353,808-\$68,640\\[15 pt]
&=\$285,168
\end{aligned}$$

Difference in Year 2:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference in NPV}&=\$353,808-\$249,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$104,808
\end{aligned}$$

There are no net present values for Years 3 and 4 of the old equipment so in these Years, the difference is $\$353,808$ for both. 

The same is true for Year 5 so the NPV difference here will be $\$634,608$

Adding together the differences in NPV, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=-\$1,272,960+\$285,168+\$104,808\\
&+\$353,808+\$353,808+\$634,608\\[15 pt]
&=\$459,240
\end{aligned}$$

Since the net present value is positive, this means that changing  the equipment now will produce a positive impact on the company's valuation.
